key_points: Colin Powell, first Black U.S. secretary of state and retired four-star general, dies at 84 from COVID-19 complications.
Powell had been diagnosed with multiple myeloma, a type of blood cancer.
He served four U.S. presidents and was the youngest and first African American chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Powell was fully vaccinated against COVID-19.
His family described him as a 'remarkable and loving husband, father, grandfather, and a great American.'
Powell's military career included two combat tours in Vietnam and leadership during the 1990-1991 Gulf War.
His tenure as secretary of state was marred by the controversy over the Iraq War, which he later called a 'blot' on his career.
Powell endorsed Barack Obama for president in 2008 and distanced himself from the Republican Party as it moved rightward.
Leaders across the political spectrum mourned his death, highlighting his service and integrity.
Survived by his wife Alma, three children, and two grandchildren.
